name: Istanbul
intro_vibe: The Bipolar Metropolis: A fractured ecosystem where the curated 'Museum City' meets the chaotic, authentic 'Living City'.

general_info.description: Istanbul is not just a bridge between East and West; it is a city of distinct 'villages' struggling with hyper-inflation and rapid gentrification. To navigate it effectively, you must shift from being a spectator of monuments to an operator of its complex logistics—mastering the ferry commute, the unwritten rules of the shared taxi (dolmuş), and the subtle political codes of its neighborhoods.

etiquette_tips: The 'Misafir' Concept: You are considered a 'Guest sent by God'. Locals will fight to pay the bill. The polite dance involves offering to pay, being refused, and eventually accepting with grace.
The 'Tut' of Negation: A sharp upward click of the head with a 'tut' sound means 'No'. It is not rude; it is efficient.
Hand on Heart: A universal gesture of sincerity. Use it when thanking someone or softening a refusal (like saying no to a carpet seller).
Tea Ritual: Refusing tea can be seen as cold. If you must, place your hand on your heart. To signal you are finished, place your teaspoon across the rim of the glass.
Communal Cats: Cats are citizens. They are allowed in cafes and mosques. Disturbing a sleeping cat is a major social faux pas.
Mosque Modesty: Shoulders and knees must be covered. Women must cover hair. Shoes off. With Hagia Sophia's 2025 rules, tourists are restricted to upper galleries.

essential_phrases.note: Say this to workers/drivers/waiters. It acknowledges their effort.

neighborhoods.name: Kadıköy
neighborhoods.description: On the Asian side, this is the stronghold of secular, creative Istanbul. It functions almost as an independent city. The 'Moda' seaside is the communal living room where thousands gather to drink beer on the rocks.

neighborhoods.name: Beşiktaş
neighborhoods.description: The energetic, chaotic heart of modern life. Home to a fierce football club and university students. The 'Çarşı' (market) is a labyrinth of bars and fish restaurants. Loud, communal, and alive.

neighborhoods.name: Fatih / Sultanahmet
neighborhoods.description: The historic peninsula containing the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. While architecturally stunning, it has been 'museumified'. It lacks organic life and becomes a ghost town after dark. Visit for history, do not stay here.

neighborhoods.name: Kuzguncuk
neighborhoods.description: A valley neighborhood on the Asian side that retains the atmosphere of a multicultural Ottoman village. Mosques, churches, and synagogues stand side-by-side. A 'Slow City' escape within the megacity.

neighborhoods.name: Nişantaşı
neighborhoods.description: The domain of the secular bourgeoisie. Manicured streets, Art Nouveau architecture, and luxury brands. It offers a European-style shopping experience and high-end dining, contrasting with the chaotic bazaars.

neighborhoods.name: Bomonti
neighborhoods.description: Centered around the historic Beer Factory (Bomontiada), now a cultural hub. On Sundays, the Feriköy Antique Market is the best place to hunt for vinyl and retro cameras.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: Tap Water: Do not drink it. Pipe infrastructure is old. Use it for brushing teeth, but buy bottled water for drinking.
Inflation & Menus: The 'Menu Law' requires prices to be visible outside. If there is no menu, walk away. Prices change weekly.
Toilets: The 'bidet nozzle' inside the bowl is standard. Use it. Public toilets often cost 5-10 TL (coins/card).
Museum Costs: Entry fees for foreigners have skyrocketed (e.g., €25 Hagia Sophia, €50+ Topkapi). Plan your budget.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Master the Istanbulkart and the Ferry.
details: Istanbulkart: The universal key. Buy at yellow machines. Note: The deposit is non-refundable. Top up in small increments.
The Ferry (Vapur): The soul of the city. Commuting between Europe and Asia with a tea in hand is the best experience in Istanbul.
Marmaray Refund: The undersea train charges the MAX fare on entry. You MUST tap your card at the 'Refund Machine' upon exiting to get money back.
Dolmuş (Minibus): Yellow shared vans. Cash only. Pass money forward to the driver via other passengers. Say 'Müsait bir yerde' to get off.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
details: Taxis: The weakest link. Drivers may refuse short rides or scam tourists. NEVER hail from the street. Use BiTaksi or Uber.
Shoe Shine Scam: A shiner drops a brush. You pick it up. They offer a 'free' thanks shine, then demand money. Ignore the brush.
Drink Scam: 'Let's have a drink' from a friendly stranger leads to a nightclub with a $1000 bill. Never go to a second location with a stranger.
Political Protests: Avoid Taksim/Istiklal on May 1st or March 8th. If you see police barricades, leave.

must_eat.description: The sesame-encrusted bread ring that fuels the city. Buy from street carts in the morning when they are fresh. By afternoon, they are rocks.
An industrial complex of small plates: cheeses, olives, jams, eggs (menemen). Avoid the 'Grand Breakfasts' in tourist zones. Go to 'Breakfast Street' in Beşiktaş.
The backbone of lunch culture. Cafeteria-style, point at what you want. Stews, rice, beans (Kuru Fasulye). Cheap, fast, and home-cooked taste.
A tavern for Rakı and Meze. It is about conversation. Toast by touching the BOTTOM of your glass (humility). Order cold mezes from the tray first.
Mussels stuffed with spiced rice, sold on street corners. Rule: Only eat at stalls with high turnover to avoid food poisoning. You pay by the count.
Grilled lamb intestines wrapped in bread, heavily spiced. The ultimate late-night food. Hygiene matters; stick to busy chains like Şampiyon.
A slow-sipping digestif. Order by sweetness: 'Sade' (no sugar), 'Orta' (medium), 'Şekerli' (sweet). Do not drink the sludge at the bottom.

items.description: The architectural marvel. 2025 Reality: Tourists enter via a separate gallery entrance (€25 fee) and cannot access the main prayer floor. Queue early.
The Ottoman imperial residence. Massive and expensive (€50+). The Harem section is essential to understand the private life of the Sultans.
An underground water reservoir with Medusa heads. Atmospheric but expensive (1300 TL). Buy tickets online to skip the line.
The 'Long Bosphorus Tour' by Şehir Hatları offers a round trip to the Black Sea for cheap. Or just take the Kadıköy-Karaköy ferry at sunset.
Sunday ritual. A massive covered market for antiques, vinyl, and retro cameras. On Saturdays, it is an organic food market.
A stunning 16th-century bathhouse restored to perfection. High-end, foreigner-friendly, and impeccable service. Booking essential.
